abstract.text: An object that implements some complex visual effects.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Depending on the desired effect, the effect may affect content layered behind the view or content added to the visual effect view’s
. Apply a visual effect view to an existing view and then apply a
or
object to apply a blur or vibrancy effect to the existing view. After you add the visual effect view to the view hierarchy, add any subviews to the
property of the visual effect view. Don’t add subviews directly to the visual effect view itself.
When using the
class, avoid alpha values that are less than 1. Creating views that are partially transparent causes the system to combine the view and all the associated subviews during an offscreen render pass.

objects need to be combined as part of the content they’re layered on top of in order to look correct. Setting the alpha to less than 1 on the visual effect view or any of its superviews causes many effects to look incorrect or not show up at all.

content.text: Use masks with a visual effect view

inlineContent.text: Masks directly applied to a
are forwarded to the internal views that provide the visual effect, including the
itself. You can also apply masks directly to the
. Applying a mask to a superview of a
object causes the effect to fail, and an exception is thrown.
Any mask provided to

isn’t the view that actually performs the mask. UIKit makes a copy of the view and applies it to each subview. To reflect a size change to the mask, you must apply the change to the original mask and reset it on the effect view.

content.text: Capture a snapshot of a visual effect view

inlineContent.text: Many effects require support from the window that hosts the
. Attempting to take a snapshot of only the
results in a snapshot that doesn’t contain the effect. To take a snapshot of a view hierarchy that contains a
, you must take a snapshot of the entire
or
that contains it.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
An object that applies a blurring effect to the content layered behind a visual effect view.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
An object that defines the properties associated with a hardware-based display.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that amplifies and adjusts the color of the content layered behind a visual effect view.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
An initializer for visual effect views and blur and vibrancy effect objects.
An object that implements some complex visual effects.
A view object that can have a visual effect view added to it.
The visual effect provided by the view.
Creates a visual effect view from data in an unarchiver.
Creates a new visual effect view with the designated visual effect.
The backdrop for your app’s user interface and the object that dispatches events to your views.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
